column12: The iiif.io website, especially the API specs; Slack; iiif-awesome when I need a sample project to show someone what IIIF can do; the viewers, especially Mirador3 but also UV and more recently Tify; Annonatate and simple annotation server for annotations; Wax for static sites is my primary hosting environment; searching code in the various Github repos for code samples.
column13: Slack is my first resource these days; I haven't used the email group for a while. I have contributed to Wax and Annonatate and have got support from the other members of those teams in developing my knowledge.
column14: I wish I could bottle it, whatever it is! I think the clarity of focus of the project and the discipline in avoiding mission creep have contributed a lot to its success. As a result the implementation problems that people come to the community with have a certain coherence. At the same time the breadth of application of IIIF technology draws people in from different fields and leads to delightful applications, which keep things fun.
column15: Supporting IIIF applications in my library is no longer my job, so IIIF is something I teach and use in my scholarly projects rather than a day-to-day responsibility. I'm therefore not keeping up to date on developments in the broad community.
column23: I've been involved in open-source in the library world since the turn of the century, and the IIIF community has somehow distilled all the best of the social behavior from that community. Nice is the norm. I don't know how that happens but it makes the community a treasure.

column41: I would need to get technological assistance to implement IIIF for our collection. We absolutely want to make the artworks and objects of our collection accessible via IIIF as soon as we make the collection accessible online. It would be helpful (in the GLAM context) to have a Digital Asset Management, to organize the images and other multimedia content related to the collection, which would provide the IIIF manifests as an integrated feature.
column42: It is difficult to understand how to use LOD, CIDOC CRM, and Linked Art when using a relational collection and museum management database (MuseumPlus) which does not natively support LOD. Using Linked Art should be made easy for all users of museum databases (museum/collection staff).

column14: The documentation and resources are wonderful.
column15: A lot of smaller institutions I work with still feel as though it's not an obtainable standard (even though some of them unknowingly have it through the Internet Archives) because of perceived technical limitations, not enough time to learn about it, etc. Even for well resourced institutions, I still see a barrier for some in understanding its basic functions and the value of those functions. The name "IIIF" also confuses people immediately and requires a slide or two in any outreach to explain. Some see community work as free labour, separate from their job duties, and it can be difficult to explain the benefits to people who see open technology community engagement in this way.
column23: "IIIF is an asset for fulfilling the CARE Principles for Indigenous Data Governance" > this is interesting and I would like to know more here. column13:
I often ask the other editors first :)
Then Slack.

column14:
On the purely practical side it meets a previously unmet need. It's not the case of it being a better answer to the question than X or Y - there is no X or Y, there is no comparable attempt to solve the same problem. E.g., for OCR text representation you could ask "should I use METS-ALTO or hOCR?" but for IIIF there is no Other.

This leads into the next point - IIIF remains successful precisely because of the things it doesn't attempt to do. Trying to cover too much ground is a danger to its success. Specs can fall apart in increasing complexity.
column15: Time! And to a lesser extent, travel costs.
column23: More work needs doing on best practices for accessibility!

column2: I have been involved in both the IIIF and Linked Art communities
column3: I see them as complimentary standards that help provide a relatively straightforward path to adoption for cultural heritage organizations that wish to model and share their data semantically. By adopting one or both standards, organizations are able to gain some or all of the various benefits of doing so, such as shared knowledge and shared tooling and software libraries.
column6: IIIF Annual Conference, A regional/informal IIIF Event (not necessarily organised by the IIIF-Consortium)
column11: Subscribed to the IIIF newsletter
column12: We have used UniversalViewer and Mirador. We also use IIIPImage which supports the IIIF Image API. I built a Level 0 compliant IIIF server from scratch that I shared and made available for download at the IIIF Conference in Rome in 2017 as a demonstration of the ease at which IIIF compatibility could be added to an organization's existing technical infrastructure.
column13: Reviewing the IIIF documentation, reviewing community forums, speaking with community members as well as those on the team developing and maintaining the specification.
column14: A shared need and a shared community of support, knowledge and expertise, and community members' willingness to develop and share tools and knowledge with others.
column15: Nothing personally, but I think to help make IIIF something that more cultural organizations could benefit from, more real-world examples need to be made available that demonstrate the "how" ‚Äì the documentation is very good in explaining the "what" and the "why", but intentionally or not, stops short of explaining how to implement IIIF within an existing organization. Yes there are may differences in technical setups between organizations, and no single example or set of examples will work "out-of-the-box" but if they are functional and well documented, they could really help more organizations adopt the standard and realize that they could do so with relatively little effort if starting at Level 0 compliance which offers a good majority of the functionality of full Level 2 compliance, without the large technical overhead and learning curve.
column23: I'm glad to be a part of it, and look forward to its continued use in more projects and by more organizations, and to assisting with its promotion and teaching.
column26: Face-to-face Linked Art Meeting, Online or face-to-face Linked Art Workshop/Presentation
column28: Subscribed to the Linked Art mailing list, Using the Linked Art mailing list, Using the Linked Art Slack workspace, Filing, reacting or responding to an issue on the Linked Art GitHub repository, Creating or merging a pull request on the Linked Art GitHub repository
column29: Speaking with community members, posting messages in the Slack channel or the mailing list, posting or commenting on issues in the GitHub repository, submitting pull requests to the GitHub repositories for Linked.Art and CROM.
column30: It is a shared community standard that is trying to help solve and provide a solution for a community need, of having a consistent and ideally standards-based way of emitting and consuming collections metadata. Its is successful because of it a shared desire for it to succeed, and the investment of time and effort by community members in adopting and promoting the standard, and their sharing of knowledge and advice.
column31: Nothing personally, but as per IIIF, providing additional documentation and possible example mapping scripts that demonstrate to others how to take source metadata and to map it into sample LOD documents could go a long way in helping newcomers understand how to use the standard and suggest possible methods for translating data from often flat/relational structures into semantically modeled data.
column39: I am grateful to be a part of the community and learn a great deal from conversations with peers, and hope I have been able to share some of the knowledge and experience I have gained over the years working with the standard and in the community. I look forward to contributing more in the months and years to come, including richer and more detailed documentation regarding how the data modeling has been achieved at our organization, and creating additional libraries and code samples that provide some practical implementation suggestions that could be used as a basis for others wanting to model their own organizations collections data.

column2: I have been involved in both the IIIF and Linked Art communities
column3:
I believe linked art intentionally follows similar community practices, and a refreshingly collaborative approach to standards, development and meetings. This should not be much of a surprise considering Rob Sanderson's role and history in both communities although I haven't spoken with Rob to determine whether the approach originated with him based on other past experiences or with Stanford.

Obviously both organizations are primarily focused on cultural heritage although IIIF has been branching out to other areas since it's technology is more generic and applicable to more than just cultural heritage whereas linked art is currently focused on... well art, and therefore has a smaller audience by definition.

column2: I have been involved in both the IIIF and Linked Art communities
column3: A number of common participants (expected, given Rob as a driving force in both initiatives). Similarity of expectation, to create a seed group among library (IIIF) or museum (LA) tech people in hopes of encouraging adoption. IIIF provides some expectation for LA folks about how long these things take to come to fruition in a first, early form. However, there are fundamental differences between them. The most important is that the IIIF use case was clearly able to be articulated and understood - it is much simpler, and perceived as a more common problem. Staff could justify spending time experimenting and learning, helping expand the community over time. LA is much harder to establish, model, illustrate, and get permission to explore.
column6: IIIF Annual Conference, A formal ad-hoc IIIF Meeting to focus on and develop the specifications (e.g. APIs, extensions), A regional/informal IIIF Event (not necessarily organised by the IIIF-Consortium)
column11: Subscribed to the IIIF-Discuss mailing list, Using the IIIF Slack workspace, Watching video recordings on the IIIF YouTube Channel
column12: The specifications, obviously. Applications we build for clients use the Cantaloupe viewer. We use other utility code to help support pipelines, optimize assets, etc.
column13: Our developer makes good use of resources from the developer GitHub sites of tools we use, and if needed the website and slack as well as his personal network of people.
column14: A clear, simple use case to be solved. Tools and specs that are easy to adopt at different levels of use, levels of skill, and for different purposes. People tend to start small, solve a specific problem, and use the tools in targeted ways. The broader aspirations of holistic use, large-scale open publishing by institutions, etc. are harder to sell internally, implement, and maintain - so we see big showcases, but the ladder from smaller, simpler uses toward more broad and large uses has a sufficient number of steps to accommodate many different people.
column15: Time and limited need for more complex features. We do what our clients need to have done, many of the capabilities are easy to maintain over time without lots of community interaction. There are things I would like to see the community explore in future to solve different kinds of needs that what IIIF is used for today (and talked with others about them), but there does not appear to be a lot of motivation and I/we do not have the capacity or additional bandwidth to go further with those ideas.
column23: It is a successful community, and appears to have a sufficient management structure and committed community leaders. And there are many benefits to having IIIF "in the toolbox." All these are good things. Both IIIF and LA struggle somewhat with their focus on *sharing* (rather than use by adopters) as a primary common good (while I agree that it can be good, it is not *necessary* in all cases, and can be a barrier to getting permission to use).
column26: Face-to-face Linked Art Meeting, Online or face-to-face Linked Art Workshop/Presentation
column28: Subscribed to the Linked Art mailing list, Using the Linked Art Slack workspace, Our lead company developer interacts with GitHub issues and code submissions, although I personally do not.
column29: Our lead developer uses the website, communication on the slack channel, and often is working things out ourselves based on common linked art patterns, because we can be ahead of where the community is in the topics they have specified.
column30: The participating community is enthusiastic and has been committed for some time. Rob and Kevin have built credibility with funders and sustained support for the group. A few institutions have made significant progress in real, demonstrable implementations (but too few, unfortunately, for the years it has been in progress). LA has built on a museum community interest in linked data and general data sharing which really began to surface in about 2012, and early promotional work like the AAC and some institutions'/consultancies' explorations have built awareness that has then attached to LA as a future "potential."
column31: This question is hard for me to answer, as we are in a unique position. We actively support the community, but the projects and problems we work on have often been ahead of where the community is working, in terms of specific areas of data they are modeling/standardizing. So we keep a close watch, engage whenever possible, but do not always have the time and funds to invest in participation in the regular bi-weekly meetings.
column39: I think it is challenging to define the word "community." There is a small group that meets regularly to discuss modeling. There is a broad interest in the wider  museum/cultural digital/data community for the *idea* of linked data to support interoperability and use. The gap that bridges those two groups is still quite large. It is possible that reaching v1.0 will help that, but the specification is centered a lot on data availability (put linked data out there and others can use it), more than on adoption, use, and advocacy/support. That hopefully will come, but it will have to broaden beyond the small core group. There is another, possibly more fundamental challenge that highlights the difference between IIIF and LA. Data is HARD. Data completeness, cleanliness, cataloguing standardization, cross-referencing/linking, classification, description, etc. are hard problems that institutions don't do well. Also, the collection management system implementation world is rife with customization, so standardization across museums is poor. This is a huge lift. Data is much harder than images. Currently there is no "ladder" (as I mentioned for IIIF) to start small, solve useful problems, and move forward incrementally. It's a much harder problem than IIIF's.
